/COMMIT_MSG.message:
They may be effectively the same, but there is a semantic difference. Netapp's undef parameters don't have a default value, and specifically rely on them being configured in order for the value to take effect.

Consider 'netapp_copyoffload_tool_path'. There isn't a default value so, in my view, having puppet's default value of 'undef' would inform me that I need to specify a value. Conversely, if I see $::os_service_default then I'd be included to think, "sure, let's go with that" and I wouldn't specify a value.

I've reverted the change about the two parameters which currently default to undef .

Checking the current implementation quickly, I still think  $::os_service_default results in the effectively same result for both these two parameters but the observation should be documented better, so I'll revisit this later and submit separate changes.

manifests/backend/netapp.pp.message: Per my comment on the commit message, this is another example where the cinder parameter has no default value, so $::os_service_default won't get you anything. Defaulting to undef may do a better job of signalling to the user that they need to explicitly set a value.

I reconsidered my previous concerns about how to handle the netapp_copyoffload_tool_path parameter, as we discussed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-cinder/+/834738.

I now agree with your approach of using $::os_service_default, which means I would vote to approve the other patch when it passes CI.

But with that understanding, we could keep the two patches separate, or merge the other one into this. I think a single patch is cleaner, so I'll vote +2 here, but withhold +W so that you can consider whether you want to merge the other patch into this one.

Thanks Alan, I'll put WIP and squash the subsequent commit to this.
Before that let me take short time to retest usage of undef in my local env, to ensure our discussion depends on the right observation.

but there are also additional advantages for using the caller function stack frame.

I can do it without caller function locals reference, using a mutable object passed as 'expected_agents_count', object that will keep the value in between calls.

If someone wants to use 'expected_agents_count' argument, he will also need to create the same "object that will keep the value" locally in caller function, the current existing approach kind of shoves it there without creating a head of time
(while also allowing parallel test execution, unlike using class variables, global variables, etc).

Also another different thing, I think it would be good to keep the last agents count value from successful check (as is), used against next check
(seems more robust if agents amount changes over time, and to not mention it every time as an argument hard coded in a test).

I was trying to generally reduce code in caller function, in order for the function 'tests.test_neutron_agents_are_alive' to be easily reusable with the new arguments, so added more code in called function.

After all this feedback, I will change some code.

In my opinion, if the last agents_count value needs to be kept, it is better to add the test_neutron_agents_are_alive function into a class, instantiate an object of that class and use an object variable to store the last_agents_count in that object.

However, I think that saving the last_agents_count value is not really needed: you just need to compare with the previous value and, if it doesn't match, raise an exception. The previous value is obtained from the length of the returned agents.
I can't see a case where keeping that value between iterations is essential, but maybe I'm missing something.
IMO, test_neutron_agents_are_alive should be agnostic of the loop where it is called. We just use this function to check the list of agents at a certain moment.

1 handler to display messages wich are not debug (info, warn, error...)
1 handler to send all debug messages to null and so don't display them.
This test check that we have one log handler if we are in debug mode.
One handler to display all log messages. Which is the behavior we wish in debug mode.

I'd have appreciated a bit of comment here explaining why we need to disable the DEBUG mode in this test.

I can imagine some people later that would wonder why this test doesn't provide DEBUG log level while others do.

oslo_service/__init__.py.message:
I'm not familiar with hubs, is it not more appropriate to move these line inside the `service_hub` function?

As it will be called at each calling of this function, thoughts?

I don't think so. This line is actually a "commit" for the line above.
The use_hub() function will take the hub definition from EVENTLET_HUB and replace current hub with that.
Without this, the EVENTLET_HUB variable will be used only if there was no hub created before it was set.

EDIT: if it makes things more understandable, we can change it to: "eventlet.hubs.use_hub(os.environ['EVENTLET_HUB'])" or "eventlet.hubs.use_hub('oslo_service:service_hub')" which will do exactly the same thing as the call without arguments.

We need this patch, virt-customize leads to machine-id generation during the image modification. This would then lead to all the OC nodes having the same machine-id, therefore
leading to some funky situation. Among them, at least for el9, ovs will generate identical MAC addresses for the vlan ports, therefore breaking all the thing and preventing OSP
internal networks (such as interal-api) to work, leading to deploy issues.

cinder/volume/api.py.message: Users can remove them manually, since the default policy for deleting an attachment is admin or owner.

-1: I believe it's not that simple, since we could get an RPC timeout error here, yet the volume service may still be processing the export/mapping of the volume, which means that removing the attachment here would make the call to `self.db.volume_attached` in volume manager's `attachment_update` method fail, leaving the volume still mapped in the backend, and some drivers then are unable to delete a volume that is mapped.

In my opinion we cannot just delete the attachment from the DB unless we also ensure that the volume is properly detached on the manager when the attachment is removed.

The current behavior is not great, but at least on an RPC timeout the volume would transition to in-use, and we could manually delete the attachment which would properly unmap the volume.

I'm ok to do the volume_detached call here on non RPC timeout cases or to leave this as it is and in the manager to the detach if the attachment has been removed.

> Felix Huettner said:
> We can actually be sure that the volume service will never process the attachment request. 
> When setting the volume to detached the volume_attachment is marked as deleted. The volume 
> manager is calling `objects.VolumeAttachment.get_by_id` at its start which whill raise a 
> `VolumeAttachmentNotFound` as the attachment has been deleted.

-1: That is not always the case, specifically in the case I described in my comment that will not be true.

This is the sequence of events that I was talking about:

[cinder-api]
- arrives to L2171 and makes the synchronous RPC call to the volume manager's `attachment_update` method and waits for a response.

[cinder-volume]
- Starts processing the request and arrives at the `self.driver.attach_volume` call, which is slow because the backend is saturated.

[cinder-api]
- the RPC call times out, because the call in the cinder-volume service is still ongoing.
- remove the attachment DB record because there has been an exception to the volume service call
- return an error to the REST API caller

[cinder-volume]
- the driver finishes the mapping operation
- manager code makes the call to `self.db.volume_attached`
- DB method fails because the attachment was deleted by the API
- The volume is left mapped in the storage array since there is no call to cleanup the mapping in the manager


If user tries to delete the volume now, depending on the driver, the operation may fail because the volume is mapped, and there is no attachment record in Cinder's DB to request a cleanup or anything like that, so an admin will have to go into the storage array's console to clean things up.

For me it seem like that we unfortunately can not determine if cinder-volume has started working on the volume already. I was thinking about checking if the cinder-volume service has ack'ed the rpc message but it seems like oslo_messaging is not exposing that information. I think this makes it impossible to actually rely on the outcome of `self.volume_rpcapi.attachment_update` to solve the bug.

As alternaitves we could prevent the duplication attachments from happening earlier in the code or clean them up when we detach the volume.

However for detaching a volume nova just removes the individual volume attachment that is in use. As we can not differenciate between removing an individual attachment and detaching the whole volume we can not use this as a trigger to clean up the additional attachments.

The other option is to improve `_attachment_reserve` to handle an additional case. (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/793136/1/cinder/volume/api.py#2128)
The idea would be that if `attachment.instance_uuid == instance_uuid` and the existing attachment is 'reserved' then we could just return this existing attachment. This would however require that `attachment_update` and `self.driver.attach_volume` are idempotent and i am unsure if this is the case.
Also this changes the API contract there can be no longer two VolumeAttachments in reserved state for the same instance. Here i am also not sure if this is intended.

If I remember correctly Nova doesn't use the attachment_create with a connector, it always creates an empty attachment first to reserve the volume and then calls the attachment_update method on line 2210 with the connector properties.  So Nova has the attachment id when the update fails and can remove the attachment in that case.  Or am I missing a case where Nova calls the create with the connector (migration or something like that)?

I think the `_attachment_reserve` change you are proposing is a good path to explore, though the `attachment_update` is not idempotent, and the `self.driver.attach_volume` call is a callback to let the driver know that the volume attachment has completed, it doesn't actually do the mapping and exporting, so it's driver dependent (though not many drivers implement it).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: The cherry pick from ussuri to train was clean.
In addition to the inline comments, this needs more unit test coverage.

It is highly likely that this action would be used whenever a drive has failed (or is suspected to have failed), so I think interacting with the physical device runs the risk of causing D-state processes.

When we find an osd is misbehaving we prefer to postpone cleanup steps till after the device has been physically removed (we simply can't trust interacting with it will ever return):
1. stop the osd process and disable the systemd unit
2. remove the osd from the crushmap (out, reweigh to zero, purge)
3. wait for the physical device to be pulled
4. cleanup luks/bcache/lvm as necessary

Could we perhaps (instead of splitting this action in remove and cleanup) try telling the kernel to forcibly remove the drive with something like `echo 1 > /sys/block/<device>/device/delete` before cleaning up? Note that I haven't tested this, I don't know if going via /sys is guaranteed to not block

That's a good point. Note that we only ever interact directly with the disks at stage 4, when we remove any bcache devices that we may have created previously. In order to avoid getting into a D-state I think a good compromise might be what Billy suggested and execute run the cleanup commands with a timeout to prevent indefinite stalling.

I wonder if it's reasonable to add a parameter to the command that allows the user to skip the device management portion itself. Naturally, a process stuck in D-state would not be a good thing (and in reality, it already *might* be in D-state when this action is run by the administrator, depending on the class of failure).

It also implies that we should run the disk cleanup commands with a timeout, so that if the child process gets stuck in D-State, well then it's stuck in D-State but the command can return to the user to indicate such a scenario.

As a heads up: I've tested 2 different scenarios to try and replicate the above situation:
- One with a device created via 'dmsetup' that has faulty sectors.
- Another with a healthy device that is removed via 'openstack volume delete' while in use.

Both worked correctly. And so, even though we didn't test unplugging a physical device, I'm confident that the implementation doesn't get stuck when a device is in D-State.

def destroy(osd_id, purge=False):

By default it would not purge unless explicitly asked and can encapsulate the details without having calling code know the particulars.

Ack

Done
There should be log entries prior to the various steps to make it more clear in debug scenarios which steps have completed or not.
Ack
using a timedelta here will make it a bit more clear imho
Done. Not sure if it's clearer. Definitely more verbose, though :P
Done

I think its probably better to have the specifics of 'purge' or 'destroy' encapsulated in the function purge_or_destroy. Encapsulating it, prevents this code from needing to know the finer details of which command are abstracted from this particular bit of code.
Ack

There's also a `ceph osd safe-to-stop` command which should probably be used here to validate that it's safe to stop the OSD in question without making data immediately unavailable [0].

[0] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/commit/bf9380457bba5a834ffa2927c73165e0f1960332

Yes, it's still needed and there's a reason why the command exists. The OSD will have had a weight and have data on it. Depending on the state of the cluster, the OSD might have a crucial part of the past history which is needed to allow data to continue a recovery effort safely. Setting the weight of an OSD may take a short amount of time, but to realize this appropriately throughout the cluster may take some more time. The critical piece is not the data that resides on the OSD, but the history that the OSD maintains. Depending on the current cluster epoch and recovery efforts, data might need to be retrieved from the OSD in order to safely rebuild the cluster.

is it needed, though ? At that point, the OSD has an effective weight of zero, and it's about to be removed, so I think it's not really needed to test for it to be safely stopped, since it's not servicing any requests anymore.
Done
